# Wait *How* Much Do Partners Make At This Biglaw Firm?
## Partners aren't making bank at this firm.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 24, 2024 at 6:44 PMApril 25, 2024 at 12:04 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/wait-how-much-do-parters-make-at-this-biglaw-firm/&text=Wait%20*How*%20Much%20Do%20Partners%20Make%20At%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/wait-how-much-do-parters-make-at-this-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/wait-how-much-do-parters-make-at-this-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Ed. Note: Welcome to our daily feature [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

According to data from 2023 collected by American Lawyer, which Biglaw firm had the lowest average compensation for all partners?

Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

# Biglaw Attorneys Are Not Being Replaced When They Leave Firms
## Biglaw isn't growing.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 1, 2021 at 5:17 PMMarch 4, 2021 at 1:47 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/biglaw-attorneys-are-not-being-replaced-when-they-leave-firms/&text=Biglaw%20Attorneys%20Are%20Not%20Being%20Replaced%20When%20They%20Leave%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/biglaw-attorneys-are-not-being-replaced-when-they-leave-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/biglaw-attorneys-are-not-being-replaced-when-they-leave-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Ed. Note: Welcome to our daily feature [Trivia Question of the Day!](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/trivia-question-of-the-day/)

According to data collected in [Leopard Solutions](https://www.leopardsolutions.com/)‘ State of the Legal Industry 2020 report, of the 200 largest law firms, how many had flat or declining attorney head count?

Hint: Leopard reports that, while hiring was down, the primary driver of this was firms not replacing attorneys — across all levels — who left their firms.

See the answer on [the next page>>](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/biglaw-attorneys-are-not-being-replaced-when-they-leave-firms/2/).

# Morning Docket: 04.03.23
## * New York braces for Trump surrender. A lot of people are talking about how it's going to be just the best surrender. HUGE. Very classy. [[Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/new-york-plans-trump-surrender-with-barricades-courtroom-closings-2023-04-02/)] * Security measures in the city follow a fake bomb threat that turned out to be a Russian ploy. Because... obviously. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/1589920)] * Fenwick & West: Which client is this federal law enforcement subpoena for? Feds: Funny story... [[Bloomberg Law News](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/ftxs-law-firm-hit-with-queries-on-work-before-crypto-collapse)] * “Disney didn’t do anything secret. They publicized it, they advertised it,” [a law professor and former GOP legislator] said. “If you’re in Tallahassee, and you’re replacing the board, how do you not know what that board is doing in their public meeting? This was negligence on the part of the governor’s office and Republican legislators.” Yup. [[Wall Street Journal](https://www.wsj.com/articles/disney-desantis-florida-reedy-creek-c46844ed)] * Judge Ho expands clerk hiring boycott to Stanford, ditching "free speech" rationale in favor of religious discrimination claim in bid to reclaim spotlight from Judge Duncan. Well played. [[Washington Free Beacon](https://freebeacon.com/campus/read-judge-james-hos-remarks-announcing-a-hiring-boycott-from-stanford-law-school/)] * Lawyers don't want to be state judges any more. If you can't drag law schools into a phony Passion play in the WSJ editorial pages, what's even the point of being a judge? [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2023/03/31/law-com-litigation-trendspotter-as-judicial-pay-loses-pace-with-prestige-courts-struggle-to-fill-vacancies/)]

# Cravath Bonuses For Everyone And A Little Something Extra For High Billers
## If you've had an extra busy 2017 you'll get an even bigger payday.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 30, 2017 at 2:10 PM
27
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/cravath-bonuses-for-everyone-and-a-little-something-extra-for-high-billers/&text=Cravath%20Bonuses%20For%20Everyone%20And%20A%20Little%20Something%20Extra%20For%20High%20Billers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/cravath-bonuses-for-everyone-and-a-little-something-extra-for-high-billers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/cravath-bonuses-for-everyone-and-a-little-something-extra-for-high-billers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Guess who’s joined the bonus party? Winston & Strawn has joined the bonus party! Yesterday the Biglaw firm announced their bonus scale for all associates, and unsurprisingly, they have followed the compensation leader Cravath. They’ll be offering market bonuses, which for those that haven’t been following are as follows:

Class of 2017 — $15,000 (pro-rated)
Class of 2016 — $15,000
Class of 2015 — $25,000
Class of 2014 — $50,000
Class of 2013 — $65,000
Class of 2012 — $80,000
Class of 2011 — $90,000
Class of 2010 — $100,000
Class of 2009+ — Case by case

In addition to the standard bonuses, Winston notes that attorneys that have “substantially exceeded the Firm’s 2,000 hour productivity goal” are eligible for additional bonuses. While “substantially exceed” is not defined, it’s still not a bad reward for associates who really worked their butts off in 2017.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
So, Winston attorneys, how do you feel about the bonuses? Feel free to sound off [by email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus), by text message (646-820-8477), or by tweet ([@ATLblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog)). A fun or insightful response — we’ll keep you anonymous — could find its way into an update to this story.

What about the bonuses everywhere else? Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text (646-820-8477), or tweet ([@ATLblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog)). We always keep our sources anonymous — and that includes our sources for bonus stories. There’s no need to send the memo using your firm email account; your personal email account is fine. Please be sure to include the memo as proof; we like to post complete bonus memos as a service to our readers. You can take a photo of the memo and attach as a picture if you are worried about metadata in a PDF or Word file. Thanks for your help.

Do you like to be in the know? Do you love gossiping with friends and co-workers over the latest bonus news? Then you simply must sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts. It’s easy, just scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks!

Read the full memo on the next page.

# Another Biglaw Firm Flocks To Match Industry Bonus Rates
## Remember, we need your help to stay on top of all the bonus news that's fit to print (or post on the internet).
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 4, 2019 at 11:43 AMDecember 4, 2019 at 9:39 AM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/another-biglaw-firm-flocks-to-match-industry-bonus-rates/&text=Another%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Flocks%20To%20Match%20Industry%20Bonus%20Rates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/another-biglaw-firm-flocks-to-match-industry-bonus-rates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/another-biglaw-firm-flocks-to-match-industry-bonus-rates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Matching the prevailing industry standard for year-end bonuses, set early in November by Milbank, is the mark of a top-tier firm. It’s a nice little bit of PR that your firm can be counted among the elite. And the folks at Willkie, Farr & Gallagher are likely welcoming the positive spin — the firm spent chunks of 2019 in the news, but it wasn’t good. If you recall, the now former co-chair of the firm, Gordon Caplan,[ got snared by the college admissions](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/willkie-farr-chair-caught-in-college-admissions-scandal/) scandal, and though the firm [quickly distanced themselves](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/willkie-farr-ditches-gordon-caplan-nabbed-in-varsity-blues-scandal/) from Caplan, a change in their PR fortunes is welcomed.

That’s good news for Willkie associates, as they issued a match of the Milbank scale. That grid is as follows:

Class of 2019 – $15,000 (pro-rated)
Class of 2018 – $15,000
Class of 2017 – $25,000
Class of 2016 – $50,000
Class of 2015 – $65,000
Class of 2014 – $80,000
Class of 2013 – $90,000
Class of 2012 – $100,000

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Willkie actually made the match way back in mid-November, but a tipster just alerted us to the news. Which brings me to my next point — we can’t do this without you, dear readers! We depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for all salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# David Boies's Fall From Grace
## Boies’s firm soldiers on and continues to rake in money by the barrel-load. Yet cracks in its once-burnished veneer are now visible to the naked eye.
By [Scott Alan Burroughs](https://abovethelaw.com/author/scottalanburroughs/)  
onSeptember 26, 2018 at 2:50 PMSeptember 26, 2018 at 8:35 PM
110
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/david-boiess-fall-from-grace/&text=David%20Boies’s%20Fall%20From%20Grace)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/david-boiess-fall-from-grace/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/09/david-boiess-fall-from-grace/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

David Boies

We live in trying times, when even those we once held in high regard continue, again and again, to disappoint us. Consider, for example, David Boies. Many aspiring litigators, myself included, were once fans, following his high-profile cases with a keen interest and holding him up as a paragon of ethics and savvy. But, as has been revealed over the course of a single, skinny year, that favorable view of Boies was woefully, almost tragically, misplaced.

When news first trickled out about his work on behalf of Harvey Weinstein, his supporters winced and his legacy began to creak and yawn. As further evidence established that this representation included an attempt at silencing, and undermining the statements of, possible sexual assault victims, and doing so in an underhanded attempt to stymie The New York Times, which also happened to be his client, that legacy tottered over and came crashing down.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
When it was later revealed that Boies was complicit in the great Theranos tragedy, people were less surprised. He had already been exposed as one whose successes resulted, at least in part, not from thorough preparation and oratory skills, but from a willingness to intimidate and bend the rules. Theranos, which claimed to possess game-changing blood test technology, was eventually exposed as a gigantic fraud. Boies was a Theranos board member and stockholder. He was also, somehow, the company’s lawyer. This conflict of interest may have been the impetus for Boies’s aggressive and distasteful defense of the company. He worked to intimidate whistleblowers, running up their legal bills and threatening litigation, and acted in a manner that Wall Street Journal reporter John Carreyrou, who exposed both Theranos and Boies, described as thuggish.

While engaging in this campaign to silence the Theranos whistleblowers, he privately wrote to the company that his work was putting him at “risk [of] being at the scene of a serious accident.” Yet, he remained on the company’s board until just before the Securities and Exchange Commission made public its allegations that Theranos perpetrated a $700 million fraud and endangered the health of its clients.

While enabling the Weinstein and Theranos disasters, Boies also somehow found time to assist in the intimidation of a young woman with the temerity to be caught up in a copyright dispute with his client. The case, which is now known as Cline et al v. Reetz-Laiolo, involved claims by Boies’s client disputing the authorship of Emma Cline’s successful book, “The Girls.” Not content to litigate the case on the merits, apparently, Boies’s team took the shameless step of threatening to exploit and publicize the sexual history of the young woman on the other side of the case for leverage. Remarkably, his firm asserted that Cline’s “sexual conduct” was central to the case, which was, to an objective observer, a simple copyright matter involving a book. And, in a telling reveal, it was reported that Cline’s attorney had to explain the concept of “slut-shaming” to a befuddled Boies.

What had become of the noble attorney who had triumphed over intimidation and retrograde sexual politics to prevail in the Hollingsworth v. Perry case, which struck down the law banning gay marriage? Gone, and, if last week’s unctuous [New York Times profile](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/21/business/david-boies-pleads-not-guilty.html) is any indication, Boies doesn’t seem much to care.

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The interview, most likely orchestrated by Boies’s publicity team in an attempt to head off the pooling flood waters of public distaste, comes off as tone-deaf and incredible. But, perhaps he had no choice but to take one final swing in the press given that, as the NYT noted, “[t]he last 12 months have been an unprecedented public relations disaster for the most prominent lawyer in America.”

While he has long had a deft touch with the press, and a strong ability to connect with others, whether they be clients, judges, juries, or adversaries, this profile reveals a defensive, dissembling, grasping attorney. One who is nevertheless far too intelligent to even half-believe half of the statements he makes in the profile, yet there they are.

He is steadfast in asserting that it was not a conflict of interest to represent the New York Times while also attempting to silence a New York Times journalist at the behest of another client, Weinstein. (With whom, the article notes with some glee, Boies had invested $10,000,000 dollars in film projects that “flopped.”) Boies notes that his attempt to “completely stop,” as his contract with a covert investigator put it, a NYT article was completely appropriate because “reporters do not have a monopoly on investigating facts.”

He goes on about one’s duty of loyalty to clients like Weinstein and Theranos, but fails to acknowledge that, while his duty to his clients is strong, his paramount duty is to the rule of law, to justice. In illustrating the importance of providing counsel to those in need, he indulges his inner Kanye and expresses a desire to represent President Trump (the article further notes that Boies tried to bring Trump in to his old firm as a client but was rebuffed).

The Boies brand of justice, apparently, is reserved for the very rich (he bills close to $2,000 per hour) and well-connected. The writer behind the profile certainly paints a picture of a man who is not necessarily in touch with the people, slipping in low-key burns about Boies espousing the virtues of “liberty, equality, and inclusiveness” while sipping on a 20-year-old Château Mouton Rothschild and being “visibly relieved that he could again indulge his craving for the Four Seasons version of pigs in blankets.”

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
“I spend a lot of money,” Mr. Boies is also quoted as saying, and his assets are noted as vast and inclusive of a vineyard. That these assets were paid for by clients like Weinstein and Theranos, who sought out Boies in an attempt to silence the truth and subdue and delay, if not impede, justice, is not lost on the reader.

Some of that money was spent by Boies’s firm to obtain the Los Angeles firm of Caldwell, Leslie & Proctor in April of 2017. Well-regarded for its entertainment and intellectual property practice, Boies and the firm’s principals trumpeted the amazing synergy that would surely result from the union. Mere months later, the Weinstein affair became public and one can only assume a large number of face-palms echoed over west Los Angeles.

Despite its travails, Boies’s firm soldiers on and continues to rake in money by the barrel-load. Yet cracks in its once-burnished veneer are now visible to the naked eye. Just this month, for example, it lost one of its top copyright litigators to a tech company. And, due to the widespread attention given to the Weinstein, Theranos, and Cline disputes, and the emphasis on how Boies apparently exacerbated the problems and dangers involved in each, no potential client will consider his firm without also contemplating whether this recent work was in pursuit of justice. And, to a small percentage at least, this will matter.

Scott Alan Burroughs, Esq. practices with [Doniger / Burroughs](http://donigerlawfirm.com/), an art law firm based in Venice, California. He represents artists and content creators of all stripes and writes and speaks regularly on copyright issues. He can be reached at [scott@copyrightLA.com](mailto:scott@copyrightLA.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column), and you can follow his law firm on Instagram: [@veniceartlaw](https://www.instagram.com/veniceartlaw/).

# Biglaw Firm Apologizes After Offering Associates Lower Bonuses Than Announced
## Yikes....
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 23, 2022 at 1:13 PMAugust 23, 2022 at 12:50 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/biglaw-firm-apologizes-after-offering-associates-lower-bonuses-than-announced/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Apologizes%20After%20Offering%20Associates%20Lower%20Bonuses%20Than%20Announced)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/biglaw-firm-apologizes-after-offering-associates-lower-bonuses-than-announced/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/biglaw-firm-apologizes-after-offering-associates-lower-bonuses-than-announced/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

‘Where’s my bonus?’

At many Biglaw firms, after bonuses are announced with much fanfare, individualized figures are presented to associates on an internal platform and sometimes they’re even confirmed by partners with a call. Those numbers are generally correct, and when the money hits bank accounts, associates are pleased as punch.

But what would happen if those numbers were wrong? What if those bonus figures were “significantly less” than what they were hyped up to be? How do you think associates would react?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Something like this happened earlier this summer at global firm Stephenson Harwood, which has more than 1,000 lawyers spread across the United Kingdom, Asia, Europe, and the Middle East. According to [RollOnFriday](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/exclusive-stephenson-harwood-sorry-after-lawyers-accidentally-promised-big-bonuses), lawyers working in the firm’s Singapore office received far smaller bonuses than what they’d been promised by partners — with some lawyers reportedly receiving “less than half as much” than the numbers they were told.

While partners were mum on the financial miscommunication, the affected associates are said to have received a verbal apology from the firm’s HR department. Martin Green, the managing partner of Stephenson Harwood’s Singapore office, offered this statement to RollOnFriday:

“We regret that a number of associates from our Singapore office were initially given incorrect information about bonus payments, which suggested that the bonus they would receive was higher than was actually awarded, and we appreciate the impact it has had on them”.

He said the mistakes were the result of human error, “for which the affected associates have received a full and unreserved apology; it shouldn’t have happened”.

“We are carrying out a thorough review of our processes and will be implementing changes to our approach, to ensure that nothing similar happens in the future”, said Green.

This is perhaps the ultimate embarrassment for a law firm of this size.

The best way to apologize to associates in this financially fraught situation would be to offer them the full amount of the bonuses they were originally told they’d receive — and then some. If anything less was offered to affected associates, then we imagine the lateral movement at Stephenson Harwood may be just as shocking as the disappointingly low bonuses associates received.

# Morning Docket: 04.25.19
## * The Am Law 100 left $4.4 billion on the table last year. Or... maybe. Biglaw offered $4.4 billion in discounts which could mean the industry undercut each other for an overall loss of value. Or it could mean the market gravitated toward what legal services are really worth. An interesting walk through the finances of Biglaw work. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/04/23/clients-are-demanding-discounts-and-leaving-law-firms-at-a-loss/)] * Some Selendy & Gay partners are headed to arbitration Quinn Emanuel over a provision in their agreement that Quinn's exercising seeking a portion of their profits on ported business. So much for my wishful thinking that the two firms would come to let bygones be bygones. [[New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/04/24/judge-dismisses-suit-against-quinn-emanuel-by-partners-of-spinoff-sends-to-arbitration/)] * Litigation funders are hiring lobbyists to push back against a new push by Senate Republicans to require more transparency -- something those same Senate Republicans spend a lot of time fighting against when it comes to... lobbyists. The circle of life. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2019/04/24/litigation-funders-flex-muscles-in-washington-keeping-lobbyists-in-demand/)] * March Madness continues in court with testimony about Arizona paying players. It's at this point that we recall that Arizona wasn't even the best college basketball team in Arizona this season. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1153369/college-hoops-defendant-discussed-bribes-by-ariz-coach-)] * EY continues its overseas legal build-out. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2019/04/24/big-fours-ey-law-has-big-plans-in-asia-292-44475/)] * Twitter's chief legal officer made $11 million last year to tell everyone that they can't do anything about Nazis. [[Corporate Counsel](https://www.law.com/corpcounsel/2019/04/24/twitter-and-paypals-chief-legal-officers-made-more-than-9m-each-last-year/)] * Supreme Court crushes class victims again! [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/supreme-court-paves-over-classwide-arbitration-route/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 25, 2019 at 8:49 AM
33
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/morning-docket-04-25-19/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2004.25.19)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/morning-docket-04-25-19/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/morning-docket-04-25-19/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

# Former Biglaw Associate Facing Charges For Possessing Child Pornography
## He's reportedly admitted to possessing thousands of child sex abuse images.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 29, 2020 at 10:49 AMOctober 29, 2020 at 9:51 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/former-biglaw-associate-facing-charges-for-possessing-child-pornography/&text=Former%20Biglaw%20Associate%20Facing%20Charges%20For%20Possessing%20Child%20Pornography)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/former-biglaw-associate-facing-charges-for-possessing-child-pornography/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/former-biglaw-associate-facing-charges-for-possessing-child-pornography/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A London-based lawyer, Faliq Mohamed Ismail, was arrested on child pornography charges. At the time of his arrest, Ismail reportedly worked in-house at Coutts, a private bank and wealth management firm. He previously worked at a series of Biglaw firms: Clifford Chance, K&L Gates, Latham & Watkins, and Goodwin Proctor.

As [reported by](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/exclusive-coutts-solicitor-out-after-admitting-possession-child-porn) RollOnFriday, Ismail “admitted possessing 1,076 videos and 2,173 images of child sex abuse which fell into the most serious category A.” He also “admitted possessing 221 videos and 2,476 images which fell into category B.” All told, Ismail reportedly had a collection of over 14,000 images, which he also admitted to sharing online.

Ismail is described as follows:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The in-house solicitor lives in a flat in Chelsea and was described as “extremely brash and flamboyant” by a source. Ismail maintained an “extremely showy-offy” Instagram account, said a source, where he posted “hundreds of pictures of himself with expensive (ladies) handbags and at fine dining places”. The account, which has now been made private, was called ‘gildedyouths’.

A spokesperson for NatWest, which owns Coutts, said this about Ismail: “We can confirm that the individual is no longer employed by the bank.”

The Solicitors Regulation Authority said this about Ismail’s arrest: “We are aware of the issue, and await conclusion of proceedings before gathering all relevant information and deciding on appropriate action.”

# Biglaw Firm Increases Salaries And Goes Up To $395K For Senior Associates
## Congratulations on the exciting news!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 17, 2022 at 11:13 AMFebruary 17, 2022 at 10:56 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/gunderson-raise-2022/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Increases%20Salaries%20And%20Goes%20Up%20To%20$395K%20For%20Senior%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/gunderson-raise-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/gunderson-raise-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Back in 1999, one daring law firm laid the groundwork for associate salaries to soar. This firm made huge waves when it offered new associates a starting salary of $125,000 — significantly higher than the $100,000 that was standard at the time. The pay raise soon spread to firms across the country, and nothing has ever been the same since.

The firm we’re speaking about is Silicon Valley powerhouse Gunderson Dettmer, and last night, managing partner [David T. Young](https://www.gunder.com/david-t-young/), notified associates that they would be matching new Milbank salary scale. Here’s a nice little note from the firm:

[W]e thank you for your extraordinary efforts to provide clients with outstanding service, recruit talented new colleagues and contribute to the firm’s growth.

This is what the new $215K salary scale looks like at Gunderson:



It looks like the firm has taken note of [what Choate did](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/choate-match-22/) and its offering even higher salaries to its senior associates instead of sticking with $385K across the board for its most experienced attorneys.

Salary increases at the firm will be retroactive to January 1, and associates will receive catch-up payments at the end of the month.

Congratulations to all U.S. associates at Gunderson!

(Flip to the next page to read the full memo from Gunderson Dettmer.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we’ll also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# The Fight To Crack Open Jones Day's Black Box Heats Up
## And Jones Day lost their Rule 11 motion.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 9, 2020 at 12:48 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/the-fight-to-crack-open-jones-days-black-box-heats-up/&text=The%20Fight%20To%20Crack%20Open%20Jones%20Day’s%20Black%20Box%20Heats%20Up)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/the-fight-to-crack-open-jones-days-black-box-heats-up/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/the-fight-to-crack-open-jones-days-black-box-heats-up/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Jones Day (Photo by David Lat)

Today, plaintiffs suing Biglaw giant Jones Day will ask a key discovery question — just how much pay and performance evaluation data will they have access to to make their case?

For those who need a refresher, [the purported class-action](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/plaintiffs-in-jones-day-gender-discrimination-case-want-it-to-be-a-class-action/?rf=1) gender discrimination [case](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/amended-gender-discrimination-case-brings-the-real-scoop-on-jones-day-compensation/) alleges a “fraternity culture” at the firm and unequal pay behind the firm’s notorious “[black box](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/the-jig-is-up-opening-up-jones-days-black-box/)” compensation system. There are currently six named plaintiffs in the case (there had been seven, but [one anonymous plaintiff dropped out](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/plaintiff-backs-out-of-gender-discrimination-lawsuit-against-jones-day-rather-than-reveal-her-name/?rf=1) rather than reveal her name). The plaintiffs are spread throughout the country — Nilab Rahyar Tolton, Andrea Mazingo, Meredith Williams, and Jaclyn Stahl worked in California offices of the firm, while Saira Draper was an associate in Atlanta, and Katrina Henderson was in the firm’s New York office — and a core allegation is that the same black box compensation systems kept their pay below that of men working at the firm.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Plaintiffs are seeking all the data for approximately 2,000 associates, while the firm seeks to limit the discovery to employees in seven of their offices, about 600 people.

As [reported by](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/jones-day-female-lawyers-want-nationwide-pay-performance-data) Bloomberg Law, the firm is arguing plaintiff’s request is overbroad and burdensome and should be limited to the offices plaintiffs worked in — not the firm’s other 11 offices — and should be limited by the statute of limitations to three years of data. Predictably, plaintiffs take a broader view:

Nationwide disclosure of Jones Day’s pay, evaluation, and personnel data is necessary for them to determine whether those systems, policies, and practices have a common discriminatory effect on female associates, the plaintiffs say in a letter brief filed July 3 with the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

It is also needed to conduct a valid statistical analysis of how the firm pays and otherwise treats its female lawyers compared to their male counterparts, the letter filed in advance of today’s status conference says.

The firm also says that discovery should be limited to “numeric” evaluations not the “narrative” performance data. Plaintiffs allege managing partner Stephen J. Brogan has a “totalitarian grip” on the firm’s black box compensation and enforces a “no whining policy” that prevents women from complaining about the compensation practice.

Jones Day [previously lost its motion](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/jones-day-loses-sanctions-push-against-women-in-sex-bias-suit) to impose Rule 11 sanctions. Judge Randolph D. Moss said, “Rule 11 is intended to deter and to punish litigation abuses. It is not a means of obtaining an early resolution of the merits of a dispute.” And he noted the pay discrimination claims “are not so frivolous or beyond-the-pale to warrant sanctions,” and discovery is necessary to determine Jones Day’s assertions.

We’ll have to see how the discovery dispute shakes out.

# How Much Would Biglaw Have To Pay You To Stay?
## There’s big money out there in staying put.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onAugust 18, 2021 at 1:43 PMAugust 18, 2021 at 11:11 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/how-much-would-biglaw-have-to-pay-you-to-stay/&text=How%20Much%20Would%20Biglaw%20Have%20To%20Pay%20You%20To%20Stay?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/how-much-would-biglaw-have-to-pay-you-to-stay/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/how-much-would-biglaw-have-to-pay-you-to-stay/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

# Anatomy Of A Rumor: The Quinn Emanuel / Williams & Connolly 'Merger' Talks
## What was the genesis of this eyebrow-raising report?
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onAugust 7, 2017 at 11:49 AMAugust 7, 2017 at 6:52 PM
33
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/anatomy-of-a-rumor-the-quinn-emanuel-williams-connolly-merger-talks/&text=Anatomy%20Of%20A%20Rumor:%20The%20Quinn%20Emanuel%20/%20Williams%20&%20Connolly%20‘Merger’%20Talks)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/anatomy-of-a-rumor-the-quinn-emanuel-williams-connolly-merger-talks/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/anatomy-of-a-rumor-the-quinn-emanuel-williams-connolly-merger-talks/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Quinn-Emanuel-Williams-Connolly.png)
NOT! (Click to enlarge.)

Last Tuesday, Biglaw was rocked by reports of supposed [merger talks between Quinn Emanuel and Williams & Connolly](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/major-biglaw-merger-news-quinn-emanuel-and-williams-connolly-are-in-talks/). The news spread rapidly, perhaps because it was so surprising.

Other than being two of the nation’s finest litigation firms with a shared reputation for zealous representation of their clients, QE and W&C share little in common. Quinn Emanuel is obscenely profitable ($5 million in [2016 profits per partner](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/the-2017-am-law-100-a-turning-point-for-biglaw/2/)), rather large ([700+](http://www.quinnemanuel.com/the-firm/about-us/) lawyers), and rapidly expanding, with offices in eight U.S. cities and more than a dozen cities overseas.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
In cultural terms, Quinn reflects its founder, legendary litigator [John Quinn](http://www.quinnemanuel.com/attorneys/quinn-john-b). The firm is entrepreneurial and risk-taking, doing a fair amount of contingency work, and it’s brash and publicity-seeking. How many Am Law 100 firms have ever [advertised in airports?](https://abovethelaw.com/2008/07/law-firm-mascot-of-the-day-lady-j/)

(Not surprisingly for the staid precincts of Biglaw, the Quinn approach has its detractors. QE’s critics — or [player haters](http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=player%20hater) — question the accuracy of its profitability, the sustainability of its expansion, and the tastefulness of its self-promotion.)

Compared to Quinn Emanuel, Williams & Connolly is [less profitable](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202794430659/Williams--Connolly-Denies-Plans-to-Pursue-Merger-with-Quinn-Emanuel?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL) ($1.6 million in PPP) and smaller (under 300 lawyers). And this is intentional. Given the tremendous talent under its roof and its worldwide reputation, W&C could be much larger and more lucrative than it currently is. But the firm has made a [deliberate decision](http://www.litigationdaily.com/id=1202794545684/Why-Its-a-Good-Thing-That-Williams--Connolly-Isnt-Merging-With-Quinn-Emanuel?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL) to focus on quality and collegiality, refusing to expand beyond its one D.C. office or even hire many laterals. As Jenna Greene noted in an interesting post-mortem, [Why It’s a Good Thing That Williams & Connolly Isn’t Merging With Quinn Emanuel](http://www.litigationdaily.com/id=1202794545684/Why-Its-a-Good-Thing-That-Williams--Connolly-Isnt-Merging-With-Quinn-Emanuel?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL):

As big law firms fell over themselves to jack up their PPPs and lure top laterals, Williams & Connolly has been like the last samurai, refusing to go with the flow. In the firm’s 50-year history, the partnership has only hired two laterals — U.S. Supreme Court advocate Kannon Shanmugam [in 2008](https://abovethelaw.com/2008/09/musical-chairs-kannon-shanmugam-to-williams-connollywcs-first-lateral-partner-in-22-years/) and tax expert Gerald Feffer in 1986. The rest are homegrown.

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
This approach instills lawyers with the Williams & Connolly culture, which is in many ways the opposite of Quinn’s. Despite its overall political liberalism — it’s zealously pro-criminal-defendant, for example, and it’s more likely to hire [a former criminal defendant](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/02/dewey-know-whos-not-going-to-trial-defendant-no-4-zachary-warren/) than a former federal prosecutor — W&C is culturally (and fiscally) conservative. It does most of its work based on hourly rates, eschewing exotic alternative-fee arrangements, and it pays [above-market base salaries](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/01/nationwide-pay-raise-watch-which-firm-pays-a-starting-salary-of-200000/) but no bonuses to its associates (who [have been wondering](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/associate-bonus-watch-which-firm-now-offers-up-to-125000-in-associate-starting-bonuses/), ever since last summer’s [Cravath pay hike](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/?rf=1), about when they’ll get a raise). And you definitely won’t see W&C advertisements in airports — heck, it took years for the firm to even [put up a website](https://www.wc.com/).

Given the big differences between the two firms, I reacted with surprise — and skepticism — to last week’s rumored merger talks. After Williams & Connolly issued its unequivocal denial, I tweeted:

I'm not surprised; this didn't sound right to me. But I am curious as to how this misunderstanding happened…. [https://t.co/ZgDLJ5oMHg](https://t.co/ZgDLJ5oMHg)

— David Lat (@DavidLat) [August 1, 2017](https://twitter.com/DavidLat/status/892496388168314883)

So I decided to do a little digging. I reached out to both firms; both declined to comment. But I also spoke to individual lawyers at both places, and here is what I managed to piece together.

The meeting that gave rise to the rumors took place not last week, but a while ago — several weeks or even a month ago. It took place over breakfast, at a Marriott in downtown D.C.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Okay, hold on right there — a power breakfast to discuss the merger of two leading law firms… at a Marriott? I have great respect for Marriott as a business and stay often at its hotels (Gold Elite, baby), but Marriott is a solid rather than glamorous brand. If the firms wanted to support Marriott International — maybe it’s a client? — they could at least have met at the [D.C. Ritz-Carlton](http://www.ritzcarlton.com/en/hotels/washington-dc/dc), Marriott’s top-of-the-line property in the nation’s capital.

UPDATE (6:51 p.m.): In defense of the Marriott pick, a source points out that it was probably the [Washington Marriott at Metro Center](http://www.marriott.com/hotels/travel/wasmc-washington-marriott-at-metro-center/) (775 12th Street NW), conveniently located down the block from Williams & Connolly (725 12th Street NW).

The breakfast involved a small number of Quinn Emanuel and Williams & Connolly lawyers. The W&C representatives were people that John Quinn knows personally at the firm, through personal friendship or prior work together as co-counsel. Some folks you might have expected at a merger-related meeting were not present; for example, W&C chairman [Dane Butswinkas](https://www.wc.com/Profiles/Dane-H-Butswinkas) did not attend, nor did all members of the Executive Committee.

What was discussed at the breakfast? The two sides disagree. The QE sources say that business matters were discussed, including referrals of work between the two firms. The W&C sources say that most of the discussion centered on families and summer plans — and that to characterize it as an official business meeting would be quite erroneous.

Near the end of the breakfast, John Quinn tossed out — somewhat spontaneously, and in very general terms — the idea of stronger ties, such as a strategic partnership or maybe even a merger. The W&C lawyers were taken by surprise, since nobody went to the breakfast anticipating such a discussion.

How did the Williams & Connolly lawyers respond? Again, there’s some divergence.

The QE sources say that the Williams & Connolly folks did not say no, at least not in a way that would satisfy a “clear statement rule.” And they claim that John Quinn followed up with W&C lawyers after the breakfast as well, which led to talk of a follow-up meeting sometime in September for further discussion.

The W&C sources disagree. Although the Williams & Connolly lawyers at the breakfast might not have been as blunt as they could have been — they were taken by surprise, and didn’t want to be rude — they made quite clear that the firm was not interested.

According to the W&C camp, when John Quinn raised the subject of a merger, he prefaced it by saying something like, “Here’s a crazy idea.” The W&C lawyers responded along these lines: “Haha, that sure IS a crazy idea! Merging with a giant international law firm more than twice our size? We haven’t opened a second office in our half-century of existence! Heck, we don’t even hire laterals!”

And that’s where things were left — until Legal Business, a U.K.-based publication, [reported](http://www.legalbusiness.co.uk/index.php/lb-blog-view/10568-quinn-emanuel-breaks-tradition-as-merger-talks-with-dc-disputes-leader-williams-connolly-begin) on the supposed merger talks last Tuesday. Their article included comment from John Quinn: “It is true that we had a meeting on this subject but it was very preliminary and we don’t know what, if anything, will come of this.”

This news quickly jumped the pond — given credibility by Quinn’s confirmation, and picked up promptly by the [American Lawyer](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202794430659/Williams--Connolly-Denies-Plans-to-Pursue-Merger-with-Quinn-Emanuel?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL), [Law360](https://www.law360.com/articles/950079/quinn-williams-connolly-downplay-reports-of-merger-talk), and [Above the Law](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/major-biglaw-merger-news-quinn-emanuel-and-williams-connolly-are-in-talks/) — and it caused a lot of tsuris over at Williams & Connolly. Senior partners and Executive Committee members were besieged by calls and emails from anxious clients, colleagues, and recruits, expressing concern that the firm they know and love was about to get transformed through absorption into the Quinn Emanuel borg. (As a litigation partner at another Biglaw firm told me, the merger rumors “created some serious consternation among W&C clients, associates, etc.  — and gave me an endless source of amusement.”)

As noted earlier, Williams & Connolly can be somewhat press-shy, even secretive. This makes sense; in many of their cases, the best result involves their client never being in the newspaper. But given all the drama, here W&C had no choice but to speak. Firm chairman Dane Butswinkas issued a [statement](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/biglaw-mega-merger-between-quinn-emanuel-and-williams-connolly-not-to-be/): “While Quinn Emanuel is an excellent law firm, we are happy just the way we are. We have no plans to merge with them or any other law firm.”

What went down here, from the point of view of each firm?

From the perspective of Quinn Emanuel, there was enough there to justify John Quinn’s confirmation of something when contacted by Legal Business. Remember that Legal Business contacted John Quinn — i.e., Quinn Emanuel didn’t make an announcement of its own — and remember his caveat that the talks were “very preliminary.” (Side note: the U.K. legal-media outlets tend to be more aggressive in their coverage of the industry than we are in the States, and they will often report out stories that we might hold pending further confirmation.)

From the perspective of Williams & Connolly, this was something spun out of nothing, and there was no way anyone could have thought that even “preliminary” discussions were underway. This was an informal breakfast meeting, not attended by W&C top brass, focused on personal rather than business matters. Yes, John Quinn randomly tossed out his “crazy idea” at the end — but that idea was not discussed further back at W&C, and certainly not discussed in the Executive Committee that runs the firm. To the contrary, many Executive Committee members and other firm leaders learned of the supposed “merger talks” the way everyone else did — from news reports.

Whose version of events am I inclined to credit? Speaking for myself, I view the W&C account as more credible. Here’s why (in addition to the fact that the talks took place over breakfast — not dinner, breakfast — at a Marriott.)

John Quinn’s incredible success, as both a lawyer and businessman, rests upon his energy, enthusiasm, and view that almost nothing is truly impossible. When he gets an idea in his head, he runs with it — over [mountains](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/07/dear-summer-associates-read-the-fine-print-before-signing-up-for-the-mountain-hiking-so-the-firm-doesnt-have-to-send-a-helicopter-for-you/), through walls, and past any obstacle standing in his way.

In many cases over his long and distinguished career, many of Quinn’s ideas — including the idea for Quinn Emanuel itself, which he launched after leaving Cravath — have turned into huge wins. But sometimes Quinn’s vision can get ahead of reality, which I suspect is what happened in this case. When he raised the idea of a “merger” with a few Williams & Connolly partners over breakfast, the fact that they didn’t explicitly say “hell to the N-O” — even if they gave many other strong indications that anyone else might have viewed as dispositive — gave him just enough of an opening to think that “preliminary discussions” were underway.

(An alternative hypothesis: John Quinn knew full well that this breakfast chat didn’t amount to “merger discussions,” but decided to confirm to Legal Business anyway. I’m not sure, however, what his motivation would be for such a move. Did he want to burnish QE’s brand by touting talks with another top firm? Did he want to make mischief for W&C? It’s all too speculative.)

If law firm consultants were to use this episode as a case study for how to conduct merger talks, what lessons would they draw from it? Here are three that come to my mind:

1. Communicate clearly. This sounds obvious, but it’s easier said than done. Despite its reputation for ruthlessness, Biglaw can actually be quite genteel — and passive-aggressive. Many lawyers like to think of themselves as learned professionals who are above money-grubbing pursuits, so they can turn skittish when talk turns to dollars and cents.

But a merger is a business deal in which money matters, so don’t be afraid to be blunt — polite, certainly, but honest. And [don’t defer difficult issues](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/11/6-things-managing-partners-need-to-know-about-law-firm-mergers/) to the post-merger integration, especially issues surrounding compensation and internal leadership, just because it’s too awkward to talk about them in advance.

2. Get leadership involved early. This is usually not a problem in most law firm mergers, where the deals originate at the top and then get sold to — or foisted upon — rank-and-file partners later. But in the rare situation where this is not the case, bring the people with actual decision-making authority into the loop as soon as possible. Otherwise you’re just wasting everyone’s time.

3. Prevent leaks. This apparent misunderstanding would never have seen the light of day if someone hadn’t leaked the news to [Legal Business](http://www.legalbusiness.co.uk/index.php/lb-blog-view/10568-quinn-emanuel-breaks-tradition-as-merger-talks-with-dc-disputes-leader-williams-connolly-begin). Again, plugging leaks is easier than said than done — just ask [Jeff Sessions](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/jeff-sessions-vows-to-make-journalists-famous-by-jailing-them-for-protecting-sources/) — but it can be done, especially if the talks take place between firm leaders and are kept inside a small group.

So that’s the skinny of how the supposed QE/W&C “merger talks” came into existence, along with lessons learned. Best of luck to Quinn Emanuel and Williams & Connolly in their — very independent — respective futures.

[Why It’s a Good Thing That Williams & Connolly Isn’t Merging With Quinn Emanuel](http://www.litigationdaily.com/id=1202794545684/Why-Its-a-Good-Thing-That-Williams--Connolly-Isnt-Merging-With-Quinn-Emanuel?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL) [Litigation Daily]

- [Major Biglaw Merger News: Quinn Emanuel And Williams & Connolly Are In Talks](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/08/major-biglaw-merger-news-quinn-emanuel-and-williams-connolly-are-in-talks/)
[David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/) is the founder and managing editor of Above the Law and the author of [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](https://supremeambitions.com/reviews/). He previously worked as a federal prosecutor in Newark, New Jersey; a litigation associate at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz; and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://twitter.com/DavidLat), [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/davidlat), and [Facebook](http://facebook.com/DavidLat), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@abovethelaw.com](mailto:dlat@abovethelaw.com).

# The 2023 Litigation Finance Survey Report
## Once a little-known option, litigation funding has become an 'increasingly standard practice,' according to our annual survey.
By [Vera Djordjevich](https://abovethelaw.com/author/vdjordjevich/)  
onNovember 8, 2023 at 2:16 PMNovember 8, 2023 at 1:30 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/2023-litigation-finance-survey-report/&text=The%202023%20Litigation%20Finance%20Survey%20Report)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/2023-litigation-finance-survey-report/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/2023-litigation-finance-survey-report/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Together with our friends at Lake Whillans, Above the Law has been tracking the development of litigation finance over the years, as it has evolved into an integral part of the legal ecosystem, offering benefits to organizations of all sizes. “It is now part of most case discussions,” one law firm partner told us.

Our annual survey of in-house counsel and law firm attorneys shows an uptick in the number of large law firms and big-name corporations who work with funders. This year, more than half of the in-house counsel who reported having firsthand experience with litigation finance work in large companies or Fortune 1000 corporations.

One element that has remained consistent across surveys is satisfaction with the experience. Among the survey respondents who have worked directly with litigation funders, the proportion who said they would do so again has remained above 80 percent for the last five years.

For more on this year’s results, including the kinds of cases that have been funded, the reasons for obtaining financing, and what lawyers consider the most important factors in choosing a financier, [check out the full report on our survey findings](https://lakewhillans.com/research/2023-litigation-finance-survey-report/).

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Lake Whillans](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/lake-whillans/), [Lake Whillans Litigation Finance](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/lake-whillans-litigation-finance/), [Litigation Finance](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/litigation-finance-topic/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Surveys](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/surveys/)

# Am Law 100 Biglaw Firm Delights Associates With Raises
## Good news for associate compensation.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 24, 2022 at 4:05 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/schulte-raises-22/&text=Am%20Law%20100%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Delights%20Associates%20With%20Raises)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/schulte-raises-22/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/schulte-raises-22/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Yay, money!

That’s the sentiment making its way through Biglaw as raises have become the order of the day. And the latest firm to announce their own raises is none other than Schulte Roth & Zabel, which took in $444,700,000 in gross revenue in 2020, making it 90th in the Am Law 100.

For those who have not yet memorized the scale, this is the new compensation grid at Schulte:

Class of 2021	$215,000
Class of 2020	$225,000
Class of 2019	$250,000
Class of 2018	$293,500
Class of 2017	$335,000
Class of 2016	$360,500
Class of 2015	$381,000
Class of 2014	$396,500
Class of 2013	$406,500
Tipsters at the firm report:

For what it’s worth, firm leadership sent out the memo first thing this morning and associates are very excited that SRZ matched so quickly. I was on several calls this morning and morale is definitely boosted with this announcement.

And like many of their peer firms, the raises will be retroactive to January 1 and paid on March 18th. Folks in the class of 2012 and more senior will have their compensation communicated individually. Read the full memo [on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/02/schulte-raises-22/2/)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Associates Disappointed With Bonuses At This Biglaw Firm
## Bonuses at this firm disappoint. Again.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 30, 2019 at 1:45 PMDecember 30, 2019 at 12:41 PM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/pepper-bonus-2019/&text=Associates%20Disappointed%20With%20Bonuses%20At%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/pepper-bonus-2019/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/pepper-bonus-2019/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Pepper Hamilton[ isn’t a stranger](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/small-bonus-pool-makes-for-sad-associates/) to disappointing bonuses. But the bonus scale released by the firm last week continues the trend. The firm announced their bonus grid, keyed to hours associates have billed, and it is noticeably smaller than the market bonuses going around Biglaw.

Here’s the scale the firm released:



[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
If the limited number of bands, as opposed to class years, is confusing, a tipster has provided an easy guide — as well as some commentary:

Level 1: 1&2+ years
Level 2: 3+4+
Level 3: 5+6+
Level 4: 7-8+ years
People may spend more than one year in the same class year or band

So essentially, even on the fastest track of leveling up (class year = level), 8th years are still making the same bonus as a first year at other firms with market bonuses

As a reminder, market bonuses as set by Milbank in November, are giving second year associates (class of 2017) $25,000. So… yeah. Though the firm also announced associates may be eligible for additional discretionary bonuses based on merit, which could bring their total bonus in line with market levels.

[Read the full memo on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/pepper-bonus-2019/2/)

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for all salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# Top 50 Biglaw Firm Comes Out Swinging With Year-End And Special Bonuses To Delight Hardworking Associates
## Another firm made associates happy with their bonus numbers.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 6, 2021 at 4:41 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/willkie-bonuses-21/&text=Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Comes%20Out%20Swinging%20With%20Year-End%20And%20Special%20Bonuses%20To%20Delight%20Hardworking%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/willkie-bonuses-21/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/willkie-bonuses-21/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This morning when Davis Polk [announced](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/davis-polk-bonuses-21/) their year-end bonuses that matched the Cravath scale — at a ~15 percent increase over last year’s bonus numbers — plus an added special bonus, well, we knew that Biglaw would respond. Since then, we’ve seen a steady stream of firms matching this scale. And after what has been a relatively quiet bonus season so far, it’s nice to see.

The latest firm to get in on that sweet, sweet bonus action is Willkie Farr & Gallagher. The firm, which took in $986,000,000 in gross revenue in 2020, making it 44th on the Am Law 100, announced bonuses, of both the year-end and special variety.

Unsurprisingly, they matched the prevailing scale:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  


As a tipster told Above the Law:

Willkie matches. Big year for the firm with two new offices opening. This isn’t surprising, but it’s still a nice way to start the week.

Congrats to associates taking home a pretty penny this bonus season. The full memo is [available on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/willkie-bonuses-21/2/).

# So Many Mistakes, So Little Time
## There's a lot of Fail to cover this week.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 18, 2019 at 4:43 PMJune 18, 2019 at 1:33 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/so-many-mistakes-so-little-time/&text=So%20Many%20Mistakes,%20So%20Little%20Time)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/so-many-mistakes-so-little-time/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/so-many-mistakes-so-little-time/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Joe and Kathryn have a freewheeling chat about legal news, which is a more professional way of saying they improvised for 30 minutes after Elie Mystal overslept and failed to show up for the scheduled recording. Above the Law is basically a late-stage rock band.

But the pair carry on and discuss Alan Dershowitz bumbling through the early stages of the defamation case he’s asked for, Brett Kavanaugh’s Supreme Court clerk hiring, Alabama Law School throwing away millions, and many more of the week’s screw-ups.

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. # Kirkland & Ellis Helps Partner, Other Firm Lawyers Escape From Israel In The Wake Of Hamas Terror Attack
## Kirkland employees worked around the clock to help get their colleagues out of the country.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 20, 2023 at 12:43 PMOctober 20, 2023 at 11:38 AM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/kirkland-ellis-helps-partner-other-firm-lawyers-escape-from-israel-in-the-wake-of-hamas-terror-attack/&text=Kirkland%20&%20Ellis%20Helps%20Partner,%20Other%20Firm%20Lawyers%20Escape%20From%20Israel%20In%20The%20Wake%20Of%20Hamas%20Terror%20Attack)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/kirkland-ellis-helps-partner-other-firm-lawyers-escape-from-israel-in-the-wake-of-hamas-terror-attack/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/kirkland-ellis-helps-partner-other-firm-lawyers-escape-from-israel-in-the-wake-of-hamas-terror-attack/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

It’s been almost two weeks since Hamas launched a deadly terror attack in Israel, and since that time, members of the Biglaw community have come together to support relief efforts. We already know that Kirkland & Ellis is [leading the pack when it comes to donations](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/biglaw-partners-make-generous-donations-to-support-israel-following-terror-attacks/), with its partners having pledged more than $1.5 million to the cause (and that amount has very likely increased by now).

Kirkland is incredibly committed to offering assistance, and the firm was on top of the situation when it came to helping one of its partners and his family flee the war-torn country in the days that followed the attack.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Kirkland partner [Daniel Wolf](https://www.kirkland.com/lawyers/w/wolf-daniel-e-pc) is based in New York City, but his parents and brother live in Israel and he has an apartment in Jerusalem. On October 7, Wolf was on his way to a synagogue when air defense sirens rang out. He ran back home to find his family gathered in a safe room, and for the next three days, they stuck it out amid missile strike after missile strike. “It was like a slow-motion horror movie,” Wolf told [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/kirkland-deals-lawyer-family-flee-israel-with-help-from-firm) of the experience. Fortunately, his story has a happy ending:

Kirkland eventually was able to help about 20 people—including other firm lawyers and their families—get on flights out of the country, after the attorneys reached out to the firm, according to Wolf.

“From the moment they found out about it, they literally mobilized unlimited resources and were in touch with us nonstop coming up with alternatives, providing escort and travel help,” said Wolf, adding that the firm’s staff stayed up all night to make sure flights took off.

Wolf may be back home in New York with his immediate family, but his heart is still in Israel as his parents, his brother, and other family members and friends remain there. While work hasn’t been easy for him considering the circumstances, he says it’s been a “welcome distraction.”

Best wishes to Daniel Wolf and his family. We’re so thankful that he was able to return home safe and sound with the help of Kirkland & Ellis.
